intro: Phonus mareoticus, commonly known as the Nile phragmites, is a tall, reed-like grass native to the wetlands of the Nile River basin. It thrives in shallow, freshwater environments and is characterized by its dense, fibrous growth habit. The plant has long, narrow leaves and produces small, clustered spikes of flowers during the wet season. It plays a crucial role in stabilizing riverbanks and providing habitat for various aquatic species. Its rhizomes are also used in traditional crafts and construction in some regions.
